Posts.Content: hi, just wondering if anyone on here bloggs outside of this site. do you recommend it and are there any pitfalls. I keep thinking about it, but not sure whether to or not !?
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: How have your friends and family reacted to your blog.  My partner is quite a private person, but I know he would support me if I wanted to do this.  ?
Posts.Title: Blogging

Posts.Content: Kusmi my drain removal was not painful at all. They are a hinderance  more than anything. I had a Mastectomy 5 weeks ago with reconstruction, I was discharged with 2 drains in, 1 was removed early as it wasnot draining much and was leaking, the other was removed about 2weeks later.  Your mum will be shown how to measure them! and I did have to go back and forth to get them checked, but that was just the set up here.  Your Breast Cancer Nurse should be able to give you information on what will happen after the op.  Have they said how many nights your Mum will be in hospital ? Also Might be worth finding a long handled bag for her to carry them round in, I used a canvas shopping bag And carried it on my shoulder.  When they removed the first one I didn't even realise it had been done, it was that quick and painless as was the second one.  We are all different, but mine didn't hurt at all. Mum will be limited to what she can do, and that can be annoying for that person especially if they are normally self sufficient.  Hope all goes well. Sending hugs x
Posts.Title: Advice please-Mastectomy with lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed at the end of April, I have had  a lumpectomy, but unfortunately my results showed more cancer and I am now due to gave a mastectomy in 2 weeks time.  I remember my diagnosis and not sleeping for the 2 nights after. I was like a zombie for about a week. You will get through this.  We have such a good network in this country and the hospitals work to strict guidelines for cancer.  I have an 18 and 22yr old, I found staying positive has really helped them and other family and friends too.
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed and terrified.

Posts.Content: I have watched it with interest. Some may not like her comment about it being do-able, but we are all examples that it is, even though it takes us through hell and back !  I hope also that as her cycles go on she can remain honest and truthful about the side effects and emotional roller coaster  she will experience. I wish her and everyone else going through this unplanned journey all the best.  By the way "Unplanned Journey" by Tiggy Walker is worth a look, mostly a photographic journey of her Breast Cancer x
Posts.Title: Anybody else been Victoria Derbyshired????????

Posts.Content: Hi all, I have been thinking in this too. I had my last chemo 12 days ago.  I have also been thinking of Yoga and mindfulness.  Will be looking into both in the New Year, my MCN is visiting me next week so I will ask her if she knows of any courses locally.  Diet wise, I was being quit healthy before all this began, I'd cut most processed food out of my diet last year, including bread, white pasta/rice and refined sugar. This  has slipped whilst on chemo as I was trying to eat half a slice of toast so I could take my anti sickness meds when i got up. I was bought chocolates by friends who came to visit, which I stopped by explaining kindly I was trying to eat as healthily as I could.  So I have decided this will stay relaxed over Christmad and then I will try to go back to my Real Food diet.  Never smoked and don't really drink, odd glass of wine with a meal out, or maybe on a weekend with my partner, I won't stop all together as I have also learnt that I still need to enjoy life.  I like walking so will try to step (pardon the pun) that up too.  Good luck to every one with their new lifestyle choices x
Posts.Title: Lifestyle changes?

Posts.Content: Shirl, sorry to but in, Can I ask where you got your shell of silicone from. I also had right sided Mastectomy with immediate reconstruction using an implant and will eventually have lipomodelling to even me out. I am using the foam shells as used in bikinis, and the soft stretchy bras I bought to wear immediately after my surgery. Fiona
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Fona, I finished chemo in December. I'm sporting a very short crop too, no style too it yet and it's dark splattered with silver, not at all like it was before. I too have put weight on.  I don't like what I see in the mirror and hate that I can't wear some of the clothes I had pre treatment.  I have some nice strappy tops I can't wear now with my reconstruction that is still lopsided, and fear I won't be able to wear that sort of thing again, do I know where you are coming from.  I have good and bad days, I do chastise myself from time to time, reminding myself that I am still here !  Love and hugs from one Fiona to another x
Posts.Title: A bit of a ramble....and a thank you!

Posts.Content: Shirl, sorry to but in, Can I ask where you got your shell of silicone from. I also had right sided Mastectomy with immediate reconstruction using an implant and will eventually have lipomodelling to even me out. I am using the foam shells as used in bikinis, and the soft stretchy bras I bought to wear immediately after my surgery. Fiona
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: hi all. Been this afternoon  for the results of my mastectomy.  They told me the DCIS was just 14mm and they got it all, so wow, the cancer has gone.  I will find out on Moday if I need chemo when they give me the Oncotype DX test results. So going out to celebrate tomorrow. We realise that we still might have a rocky road ahead if I need chemo, but we will know that it will be preventative !
Posts.Title: NEDdy

Posts.Content: Yes I'm ER+, will be on tamoxifen for 5-10 years. Just want to know what next step is.  But at least I know the disease has gone. X
Posts.Title: NEDdy

Posts.Content: Hi Kaybee, my story is very similar to yours, had WLE and sentinel node removal, DCIS was found in my margins so had a mastectomy and reconstruction just weeks later, I was told there was no evidence of disease after that but that I needed chemo so that was started 2weeks late.  I am now halfway through my chemo.  You have been through a lot, we are human, not machines, we have emotions that catch us out sometimes. I seem to get through my surgeries well, but the chemo news which I was hoping not to hear hit me hard.  I think everything caught up with me and my emotions were everywhere.  We have a lot to deal with, you have a new image to come to terms with and that in itself is hard.  Try not to be too hard on yourself, everything takes time.   Don't forget the end game in all of this is to be cancer free, you were probably told when told everything go clear, that there was no evidence of disease, that makes you a member of the NEDdy club, so that's something to celebrate X. You could also join the miserable cows club if you feel like venting off, we are all here to support each other through the good and not so good x
Posts.Title: Down

Posts.Content: I want my hair back too.  I had my last chemo on 3rd Dec.  I have noticed a bit of fuzz so I hope this is the start of the regrowth.  Hair loss has been so hard, I'm wearing scarves as I don't get on with my wig. Over Christmas I hated the fact that I couldn't glam up, normally I would put a nice outfit on and do my hair, this year whatever outfit I thought I might wear, just didn't look right with whatever headwear I tried.  I also have to tackle going back to work in the coming weeks wearing scarves.  I don't like the way I look and have to keep telling myself, it has all happened for a reason.  I try to remain positive but just like the rest of you I have low moments x
Posts.Title: I'm not 'me'

Posts.Content: Does anyone know if you are able to take sage if you were ER positive.  I've been in citalopram, didn't agree with me, then Clonidine which did work, but lowered  my blood pressure dangerously, so that has been stopped.  Next ste is to try sage if allowed ! Fiona
Posts.Title: Very bad flushes

Posts.Content: This is what I posted on my Facebook account yesterday "A year ago today I underwent surgery that has saved my life and changed my body and changed my outlook on life.  I am very blessed and owe much to my very supportive friends and family, and all the medical professionals who have been involved in my treatments and recovery.  It is also a year that  I met my lovely friend Pat who was also undergoing surgery, I now have a life long friend in her.  Life is for living ! X". Happy 1yr Anniversary Mrs D, how sweet that Wayne remembered X
Posts.Title: A Year On

Posts.Content: GnJ,  Mrs D, is OK, but she lost her Dad recently, so has been going through an emotionally upsetting time.  I will tell her you were asking after her x
Posts.Title: A Year On

Posts.Content: Hi all.  Everything went fine.  I did find myself however nearly running through the turnstile to get to my office. The only downside was our fire alarm went off and we were stood outside in the rain for 30 mins, I wasn't impressed. J, I did my coffee morning early. I held it on 5th Sept at home and raised £367. X
Posts.Title: Work with head scarf on !

Posts.Content: wish me luck folks. Just about to set off for work first time rockin the head scarf.  went to work a couple of weeks ago with my wig on, but I am struggling to get use to it, so I am wearing hats and scarves more. My scalp is sore at the moment so wouldn't cope with the wig at the moment.  It has only taken me about an hour to decide which headwear to wear, what colour etc.  I know I will get some second glances, just hope I am strong enough to cope with that.  I am fine out and about with scarves on, but work is different, this is a place full of people who know me.   Well here goes ! X
Posts.Title: Work with head scarf on !

Posts.Content: Hi All.  Been for my Oncotype DX results today.  My result was slap Bang in the middle, that infamous grey area. Doctor is recommending chemo due to strong family history and a tumour smaller than a micro cell in one lymph node.  So in approx 2 weeks I will start 6 cycles of EC.  Even though we were expecting it, I think we were clinging on to the smallest hope that it might not be needed!  Oh well, onwards and upwards. X
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: I would just like to say that this afternoon I have my first cycle of EC.  this is new territory for me, and normally I would say that I am stepping into the unknown, but with the help of this site, you lovely people and the information I have gleaned from this post, It is not totally unknown, I feel forearmed. X
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: G n J,  I've only had my first cycle, but was amazed at how tired I would get without warning. Yesterday and today have been my best days yet.  Managed 4 hrs at Caddie on Saturday but stayed at home on Sunday, knew the full day would have been too much,  that allowed my partner to go on his bike, which he really enjoyed !
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: hi all, I start my chemotherapy this Wednesday, I will be having 6 cycles of EC. I have met my nurse who will be looking after me during this time.   Have also had a couple of coffee meetings with the lovely Mrs D (Pat) who has shared some of her knowledge and experiences. Hoping I won't react too badly and am on top form again at the weekend so I can go watch the Superbikes at Cadwell Park on Sunday with my amazing partner who will be going with me on Wednesday for my first session. I am sure I will be a regular visitor to this group this month and a few more x
Posts.Title: 1st cycle of EC this Wednesday

Posts.Content: Aargh, my little cutie Johnny !  Thank you G & J x
Posts.Title: 1st cycle of EC this Wednesday

Posts.Content: Hi Dachess First EC session went welL.  I will admit I was a little anxious in the morning. While sat in the waiting area I was telling myself that Many people go through this everyday, it's all for the best reason even though we know some of the side affects can be not so nice, so I gave myself a talking too, braced myself and walked in with my partner holding my hand.  Everyone was so nice and jolly, these nurses and even the volunteer making tea are true Angels. You will be fine. You might want to join the Chemotherapy group on here.  There are not many of us on EC, but many on FEC, so we get similar side effects.  You will probably get an appointment just before your first session where they will go through everything with you, if so, take someone with you, there is a lot to take in, most  will be repeated in the written info they give you to take home. I will send you a friend request so you can PM me if you wish and I will go through it in more detail.  Take care, stay strong x
Posts.Title: 1st cycle of EC this Wednesday

Posts.Content: Hi Carole, I can't really comment on this  but just wanted to send out a hug.  It is all of ours fears, that this dreaded disease will come back.  Hope it turns out to be nothing.  I'm sure others will be along to comment soon, and hopefully someone who has had similar. X
Posts.Title: Another Lump

Posts.Content: Hi, I know some ladies on here have had lipomodelling as part of their reconstructions.  Just wondered how many were advised not to diet when having lipomodelling  I was not, but read it on an NHS related site.  Makes sense really, I had this procedure last week, and have to say my stomach is still sore, my surgeon joked that I should have eaten more mars bars.  I am on Tamoxifen and find unless I am careful with what I eat, the weight piles on, so I am trying to be good, but now I am wondering if I should wait till after I have had all my procedures done.  any thought ?
Posts.Title: Lipofilling and dieting

Posts.Content: I had immediate recon with implant. The lipofilling is to soften the look,  fill in dents and even me up.  I am not overweight for my height but have been trying to trim down slightly, or even keep my weight constant which is a battle against Tamoxifen ! but the article I read says to avoid dieting when going through this procedure.  Think I might relax and enjoy the odd biscuit etc for a while.
Posts.Title: Lipofilling and dieting

Posts.Content: Hi Debs,  should have also said that the main thing is hydration.  Drinks lots and lots of fluids, I couldn't face tea for the fist 7-10 days after each cycle and normally drink lots of it, I took to drinking water with slices of lemon and milky coffees and other cordials x
Posts.Title: starting epurubicin & cycophosomide chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Debs, I had 6 cycles of EC, my last one was 3 Dec.  As already explained, it is very similar to FEC, with much of the same side effects.  Make sure you take the sickness meds as prescribed, don't think that you don't need them.  I found eating little and often helped with nausea.  I was very tired and out of sorts straight after each cycle for a day or two.  I did suffer the chemo mouth, but found the mouthwash given to me (Difflam) was a real help.  My hair started coming out on day 15 of 1st chemo, so I had my head shaved and started wearing a wig, but didn't get on with it so I have been wearing scarves and hats.  Good news is, my hair is starting to grow back !  Stay positive, this is so do able X
Posts.Title: starting epurubicin & cycophosomide chemo

Posts.Content: Good luck to you and Wayne on your new venture. Don't go over doing it!  Ooh and put me down for the name card if you have spaces available.  I'll pm you X
Posts.Title: My new life.

Posts.Content: Hi J. Sounds so familiar.  I get so emotional so quickly.  I was only thinking the other day, I will never be the pre diagnosis me, I feel older, fatter, and I don't look like me in the mirror.  But as my wiser partner told me the other morning whilst wiping my tears away after I had a meltdown, it's been over a year since diagnosis, I was always going to get older, time doesn't stop, with age comes more aches and pains, my hair will eventually grow long enough to style, and most people put a bit of weight on through the years too.  I do love him so much.  I agree with fundamentals, we are feeling grief, grief for what has been taken from us, And grief for the old us.  We've somehow got to get our heads round the new us and make the best of what we have, but maybe we need time to grieve first.  I too am trying to keep busy and have weekends away and holidays planned.  Live life to the full X
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: Sorry for your loss Judith x
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: Hi Lou. Don't be scared.  I am sending this from my hospital bed, I have just had right side mastectomy and immediate construction using an implant.   There are many different options for reconstruction but your nurse will go through them with you.  I knew straight away I wanted reconstruction but it was a bit of a minefield making the right choice.  There are many people on here who have had the different types reconstruction. You will get plenty of advice and support here. My op was on Tuesday and I am hoping to go home today. You will be on hell of an emotional roller coaster at the moment,  take your time to let the news sink in then look into your options.  Take care
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O

Posts.Content: Hi Gina, I'm 46 with 2 children, divorced but with a new partner, so I am very similar to you. I had a Mastectomy on Tuesday with immediate reconstruction.  Dont know If you are having reconstruction?  I had my concerns too before the op.  It's natural !!  I found it harder hearing I needed a Mastectomy than my diagnosis of Breast Cancer, seems stupid now !  But it wasn't stupid, a couple of weeks ago, I worried about how I would look, how I would feel, how my partner would feel !!  I am a worrier !  My partner has been amazing, suppose it helps him being more of a leg man lol !  He has told me he will love and support me through all of this, he could have run a mile but he hasn't, and I love him more each day for the love he had and is showing me.  My family and my sons too are lending their support.  I have one son moving in today to help me while my partner works this weekend.  I tried to keep busy too, and yes it's those moments when you are all alone that all your concerns hit you.   At home now I am so glad I had the mastectomy, that op has taken away the cancer and given me the chance to see my sons grow into men and have a new life with my partner.  I was lucky not to have node involvement, but even that doesn't necessarily mean it has spread else were.   Please try and look at the bigger picture, the mastectomy hopefully will remove all the cancer, and any other treatments are also to clear you of this nastiness. We are all very lucky to have each other on this forum and the amazing teams at our hospitals.  If you would like to private message me, feel free, and write down all your fears, it may help to get it all off your chest,  I don't know your full history, but I can tell you about my recent surgery if you would like to know about it. I am not a doctor but we can share our worries etc, that's what we do on here, support each other how we can.  Fiona x
Posts.Title: Struggling on the inside
